awd_titl_txt: A Multifaceted Examination of the Development and Application of Antidiscrimination Laws
awd_abstract_narration:
This study aims to develop research models to comparatively analyze the effectiveness of anti-discrimination laws, with a specific focus on the justice and legal educational systems within which those laws are developed. The project advances sociolegal, sociological, and legal anthropological understandings of the impact of protective legal frameworks on society. The project provides funding for the training of one graduate student in methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, and broadens the participation of underrepresented groups in scientific research. Project data and findings would be disseminated to improve the public's understanding of science and the scientific method, which would include the creation of a workshop for K-12 teachers, and the development of specific course modules for university and law school students.

The researchers plan to explore how anti-discrimination laws have been developed and applied and understood within the justice and legal educational systems. The project examine the application of two categories of legal instruments: articles of constitutions and special laws that recognize and protect identity-based collective rights over resources and cultural practices; and constitutional articles and special laws that have for objective to protect against discrimination. The research takes place in a juridical context where these laws are institutionalized, and incorporated into legal curricula. The project asks how laws are designed and adopted; how they are applied in the practice of the justice system; what obstacles prevent their successful application; and more generally whether these laws have been effective. The project combines sociolegal archival, ethnographic observational research methods in law schools, and interviews with plaintiffs, lawyers, prosecutors, defense attorneys and judges. This project will assess qualitatively and quantitatively the level of knowledge the justice system operators have about such laws; compile a detailed list of all relevant litigations; collect the cases' archives; and interview the social actors and justice system operators involved. The project makes critical contributions to legal anthropology and sociolegal studies through an analysis of how knowledge about longstanding legal protections designed to mitigate the impacts of discrimination are produced and circulated.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the application of "ethnoracial law" in Ecuador's judicial system for the defense of Afrodescendants' rights.  "Ethnoracial law" refers to the laws adopted with the turn towards multiculturalism in Latin America since the end of the 1980s, which has been unfolding originally in each national context.  These laws either recognize ethnoracially-based collective rights or provide protections to minorities against discrimination.

International Context and Ecuadorian Reality

Our findings confirm that international ethnoracial legal instruments, designed to protect the collective rights or address existing discrimination against ethnoracial minorities, are generally more progressive than national-level legislation. This international framework offers crucial protection for vulnerable groups in Latin America. However, the Ecuadorian context, while embracing a "multicultural turn" and adopting new constitutional and legal instruments, also reveals a complex reality. The initial enthusiasm surrounding the creation of these laws—a hallmark of the "new Latin American constitutionalism"—was followed by disappointment because the intended social improvements failed to fully materialize. This discrepancy between initial utopian aims and the on-the-ground reality highlights the gap between legal frameworks and their actual implementation.

Judicial System Operators' Knowledge of Ethnoracial Laws

A key component of our research involved assessing cualitatively and quantitatively the knowledge of ethnoracial laws the operators (judges, prosecutors, practicing attorneys, public defenders) of the judicial system have. Survey results indicate that while a majority of respondents (70%) were aware of legal instruments recognizing and 'protecting collective rights, only a smaller percentage (59%) were knowledgeable about anti-discrimination laws. The Constitution was overwhelmingly identified as the most well-known instrument protecting collective rights, followed by laws on national equality councils and intercultural education. Conversely, the Penal Code was most recognized as an anti-discrimination instrument, followed by the Constitution. It must be emphasized that judicial system operators' knowledge about ethno-racial legal instruments point to a preeminence of the 'indigenous condition' in the field of alterity.

Indigenous Focus and Marginalization of Afrodescendants

The data reveals the significant preeminence of Indigenous populations when considering ethnoracial alterity, which contrasts with the marginalization of  Afrodescendants. Both legislators and judicial operators primarily focus on Indigenous issues, leading to a marginalization of Afrodescendant concerns in legal processes and social discourse. This imbalance needs urgent attention to ensure equitable application of the laws and effective protection of Afrodescendants' rights.

The Role of "Race Regulation Customary Law"

Our analysis of emblematic litigations involving Afrodescendants attempting to defend their rights reveals the influence of what Tanya Hernandez terms "race regulation customary law." This informal system of beliefs and practices related to race profoundly impacts legal outcomes, often hindering the efficacy of ethnoracial laws. Examples include intimidation of Afrodescendant complainants, judicial bias in favor of white or white-mestizo defendants, and manipulation of police and other regulations to shield perpetrators of anti-black racism and discrimination from accountability. These issues expose the limitations of relying solely on formal legal frameworks to address systemic racism.

Curricular Gaps and Educational Reform

The research uncovered critical gaps in legal education. Many law school curricula lack adequate coverage of ethnoracial laws, particularly those addressing anti-discrimination. Where ethnoracial laws are addressed, the focus heavily leans towards collective rights for Indigenous populations, almost completely overlooking Afrodescendant concerns for the same rights. Focus group discussions with law students confirmed these deficiencies and underscored the need for significant curricular reform. Students demanded an intersectional approach to legal education, acknowledging the complexities of race, gender, class, and other social factors in shaping experiences of discrimination. They also expressed a desire for more effective training on subtle and explicit forms of racism and discrimination, as well as the non-readily visible psychological damages they cause.

Broader Impacts and Future Directions

The project's broader impacts encompass several key initiatives. We have donated the emblematic litigations' archives to the Observatory of Justice for Afrodescendants in Latin America (OJALA) housed at FIU.  OJALA has the ambition to develop of repository of emblematic cases involving the rights of Afrodescendants from across the Latin American region.  We have developed a web-based learning module to be used and integrated within graduate courses in various disciplines. Our findings will be disseminated through various channels, including symposia, publications, and policy-oriented texts, aimed at promoting a more just and equitable legal system for Afrodescendants in Ecuador and Latin America.

The research highlights the fact that legislation alone is insufficient to remedy current situations of disrespect of Afrodescendants' rights. Effective change requires increased public awareness, improved legal education, and a concerted effort to challenge the ingrained biases that continue to perpetuate systemic racism and discrimination against Afrodescendants in Ecuador. Future work should focus on translating these findings into concrete policy recommendations and sustained advocacy efforts.
